page.title: 15Colvend: Local History
page.content: Man has undoubtedly lived in these parts since Stone Age times but the Motte of Mark is the earliest of our ancient monuments. It was an Iron Age fortress and stands on a hill near Rockcliffe overlooking Rough Firth. The most colourful period was in the days of the 18th Century smugglers.The Isle of Man was a distribution centre for brandy,tea,salt and tobacco from France.The smugglers came across the Solway Firth and beached their ships on the rocky Colvend shore.They hid their merchandise in the caves along the coast until it could be taken over the hills to Dumfries by "Longtownmen" The Customs and Excise men were constantly on guard along the cliff tops. At least one man is known to have been shot by the Excisemen,and a monument on Castlehill marks the spot where another was drowned.
